item.title: Sophie Robinson: How to design a bathroom you'll want to spend time in
item.description: For our columnist Sophie Robinson, shiny surfaces and hard tiles have given way to a warm, lived-in space perfect for relaxing in. She tells us how to use colour to create a sanctuary you’ll never want to leave
item.author: Sophie Robinson
item.source: Sophie Robinson: How to design a bathroom you'll want to spend time in

media:content.media:title: Sophie Robinson on designing a delightful bathroom
media:content.media:description: For our columnist, shiny surfaces have given way to a warm, lived-in space perfect for relaxing in. She tells us how to use colour to create a sanctuary.

item.content:encoded:
When you're designing a room in your home, always begin by asking yourself three simple things: What will you be doing in the room? When will you be doing it? And how do you want to feel in the space?

Having the answers to these questions stopped me making the wrong decisions when it came to decorating our family bathroom.

We have a separate shower room with a WC, and as a family we are out of the splashy toddler years, so this room is for brushing teeth in the mornings and having a long soak in the tub in the evenings. Keeping these factors in mind allowed me to approach designing this room in a different way than I would otherwise have done.

I intentionally avoided the gleaming, clinical feel of an all-tiled white bathroom and instead approached the design as I would a living room. Colourful wallpaper, soft fabrics, paintings and decorative lighting are not things you necessarily expect in a bathroom but they can work brilliantly.

Tiles, while practical in very wet areas, can feel hard and cold and are acoustically noisy, so I substituted them for engineered wood flooring, and splashbacks behind the basin and bath are in painted bathroom-grade tongue-and-groove panelling.

And wallpaper! Yes, you can have wallpaper in your bathroom if the room is well ventilated. Just keep it away from wet areas, such as shower cubicles and splashbacks. Apply a coat of decorator's matt varnish to protect it from moisture damage, and it can last for years.

Yes, you can have wallpaper in your bathroom!

My aim was to create a cosy feel, which I achieved by accessorising with a fluffy Moroccan rug and rattan furniture as well as an antique foxed mirror and plenty of plants. A vintage oil painting picked up for peanuts at an antiques fair, and my grandmother’s collection of plates all add to the charm.

A palette of cream, brick red and mustard yellow creates a feeling of warmth, and I even painted the outside of the bath myself, which is easy to do with an all-surface primer applied first.

All in all, everyone loves this room and three years on it's still looking picture perfect. And best of all, it has a lock on the door, making it my favourite place to escape to, take time out and relax.

Sign up to Sophie's online course, Be your own interior designer.

Follow House Beautiful on TikTok and Instagram.

item.title: ‘We wanted a bathroom with a luxe but laidback feel’
item.description: Thanks to an elegant makeover, a former nursery is now a very grown-up space.
item.author: Holly Ransome
item.category: App: Room Renovations,News,Home,Renovate,App: Bathroom Renovations,Homes & Makeovers
item.source: ‘We wanted a bathroom with a luxe but laidback feel’

media:content.media:title: ‘We wanted a luxe bathroom with a laidback feel'
media:content.media:description: Once a baby's nursery, this light and airy bathroom now provides a serene space for the parents – and it's a masterclass in simple sophistication.

item.content:encoded:
Once a baby's nursery, this light and airy bathroom now provides a serene space for the parents. Pared-back yet glamorous, with subtle Art Deco references, it's a masterclass in simple sophistication.

Who lives here

Maria Emerson and her husband Tom live with their young daughter in a Victorian house in Putney, south-west London.

Before

ME: The room adjoins our main bedroom and used to be our daughter's nursery, but now she's a little older she's happy in a larger room upstairs. Originally the doorway was on the other side of the room.

Tell us about your plans for this room...

ME: Our aim was to create a functional, modern space with a glamorous look. It was important to us that we add lots of warmth and texture, and we tried to give a nod to Art Deco style, and even had in mind the grandeur of ancient Greece. The wooden fluting makes it feel elegant while still being perfectly practical.

How did you get started?

ME: We enlisted the help of specialist design company Simply Bathrooms in Surrey for the planning. It offered a full design service and created 3D visual plans, so we knew what the layout would look like. Having renovated a bathroom in our previous home, this time we wanted extra specialist support!

Did you have to overcome any hurdles?

ME: Deciding on the best layout proved tricky. The room is a good size, but the position of the chimney breast limited our options. We wanted a large vanity unit, bath and walk-in shower, so had to be clever about maximising space. This meant moving the doorway and installing a sliding door – and we went for a smaller-than-full-size tub. The bath looks stylish without taking up much room, and we can enjoy the garden view while having a soak.

What were your must-haves?

ME: It was all about how the space made us feel. We wanted to ignore trends and come up with something unique and timeless that felt distinctly ours. For example, the terrazzo countertop basins are not an obvious choice, but they make the room feel more individual and eclectic.

Are you happy with the final result?

ME: Very much so. We're obsessed with the wooden panelling, which elevates the room, but the wall tiles are the real unsung heroes. We wanted something neutral that looked smart but not clinical, so were happy to find these ones from Ca' Pietra in a mix of white and warmer off-white tones. The textured surface looks handmade, but they're super-practical, easy-to-clean porcelain. We've got exactly the modern bathroom we wanted.

Sourcebook

  • Slipp bath, bcdesigns.co.uk.
  • Vos bath mixer tap, basin valves & spout, shower head & towel rails; all jtpuk.co.uk.
  • Gallery 10 shower screen, crosswater.co.uk.
  • Uni WC, saneux.com.
  • Docklands rectangular mirrors, originsliving.uk.
  • Terrazzo basin, vanity unit & fluted oak wall panelling; all simplybathroomsltd.co.uk.
  • Wall lights, pooky.com.
  • Metro wall tiles & Louvre floor tiles; both capietra.com.
  • Walls in Mizzle matt emulsion, farrow-ball.com

Costs

  • Bath £1,986
  • Bath tap £950
  • Shower £1,203
  • Basin taps £658
  • Towel rails £718
  • Shower screen £827
  • WC £788
  • Basins £500
  • Vanity unit £2,779
  • Lights £216
  • Tiles £2,000
  • Mirrors £350
  • Oak panelling £2,000
  • Paint £68
  • TOTAL £15,043

Follow House Beautiful on TikTok and Instagram.

item.title: ‘Our goal was for an elegant and spacious bathroom’
item.description: Turning a compact bathroom into a wet room has opened up this space.
item.author: Carolyn Bailey
item.category: App: Room Renovations,Home,Renovate,App: Bathroom Renovations,Homes & Makeovers
item.source: ‘Our goal was for an elegant and spacious bathroom’

media:content.media:title: ‘Our goal was for an elegant & spacious bathroom'
media:content.media:description: This elegant pink bathroom in north London, complete with brushed-brass finishes, is unrecognisable thanks to a total revamp.

item.content:encoded:
This elegant pink bathroom, complete with brushed-brass finishes, is unrecognisable thanks to a total revamp. Complete with clever alcove shelving and a handy heated mirror, it has been designed to perfection with quality fixtures and fittings.

Who lives here

Katerina and Mark, both software engineers, live in a Victorian terraced house in Highbury, north London.

Before

'The house has a single small bathroom that looked even smaller with a bathtub and a bulky basin,' says Katerina. 'The layout of the room was fine, but there was very little storage space.'

What kind of look did you want?

Katerina: Our aim was to make the bathroom look more elegant and feel spacious. We decided to have a wet room and add luxe touches with brushed-brass finishes. Also, we were inspired by Farrow & Ball's Setting Plaster shade and wanted to use it on the walls and ceiling to give an illusion of extra height.

How did you get started?

Katerina: As we had a fairly good idea of what we wanted, we created a Pinterest collection of images for reference and found specific photos for the tiles, the wet room, the basin and cabinet. Then we went to Ripples with a drawn layout of the existing room and its dimensions to start the conversation and see what was feasible.

Were there any particular challenges?

Katerina: The main one was the size of the bathroom, which is only about 2x1.8m. We wanted to fit everything in and feel comfortable, not cramped.

You had certain priorities in mind...

We were keen to have underfloor heating, a heated mirror, an overhead and hand-held shower, more storage space and alcove shelving in the shower.

Now it’s done, what do you like most?

Katerina: Our finished bathroom is exactly what we wanted and has been designed to perfection. The tiles laid in a herringbone pattern look great and the quality of the fixtures and fittings is excellent.

The sourcebook

  • Setting Plaster matt emulsion, farrow-ball.com.
  • Cifial shower; The Shower Lab screen; Finwood Designs basin; Cifial basin tap; Bard & Blackwood vanity unit & shelves; Laufen WC; Ca' Pietra Carter Metro wall tiles; Mono Hex floor tiles; Docklands mirror by Bathroom Origins; all ripplesbathrooms.com.

Costs

  • Waterproofing £1,025
  • Paint £52
  • Shower screen £915
  • Shower mixer £1,160
  • Shower head £430
  • Wall-mounted shower head £645
  • Basin £540
  • Basin tap £555
  • Worktop £180
  • Vanity unit £916
  • Shelves £576
  • WC £533
  • Wall tiles £983
  • Floor tiles £416
  • Mirror £185
  • Total £9,111

Follow House Beautiful on TikTok and Instagram.

item.title: ‘Our bargain bathroom feels anything but’
item.description: Thanks to eBay finds and canny shopping, this luxury bathroom came in on budget.
item.author: Alexandra Cunningham
item.category: App: Room Renovations,Home,Renovate,Home Improvement,App: Bathroom Renovations,Interior Design,Homes & Makeovers

media:content.media:title: ‘Our bargain bathroom feels anything but’
media:content.media:description: Thanks to eBay finds and canny shopping, this luxury bathroom, in a Victorian house in south-east London, came in on budget.

item.content:encoded:
A £50 bath and a basin snapped up on Facebook Marketplace have helped create an expensive-looking bathroom in what was previously a bedroom.

Who lives here

Vic White, a journalist (@weboughtalondonhouse), lives in a five-bedroom Victorian house in south-east London with her husband Peter and son Seb.

Before

‘Originally this space was a bedroom, but as our new loft extension provided us with two extra bedrooms, we were able to turn this one into a large family bathroom,' says Vic.

What style were you going for?

VW: I decided to go quite 'maximal' with lots of different textures and colours, which is not my usual style. My previous bathrooms have been quite modern and simple with grey or white fixtures. I'd seen a lot of people on Instagram doing more elaborate bathrooms and, as we had uncovered a gorgeous marble fireplace in the room, I decided to go for it this time.

How did you plan the layout?

VW: A freestanding bath was top of the list, so that was the first thing to think about. We used Frog Tape to outline its shape on the floor, then lay down within the space to see how it would feel in different areas of the room. The best place in the end was under the window, as you can lie in the bath and see the sky.

Where did you get your fittings from?

VW: All over! I bought the bath first on eBay for just £50 – I think the sellers just wanted rid of it. It's very heavy, so we enlisted some help from a friend with a van and strong arms. I then sold the taps that came with the bath on eBay for £50, so it ended up being technically free. We added a countertop basin to a chest of wooden drawers (bought via Facebook Marketplace) to serve as a vanity unit. I searched online for everything else.

You’ve been quite bold with colour...

VW: Yes – I love the burnt orange Hoxton tiles from Mandarin Stone, so planned the rest of the scheme around them. We were worried about mixing the black modern fittings with the more traditional brass taps, but I like how eclectic it looks. The black window frame and shower screen pull it all together. I went for Setting Plaster by Farrow & Ball on the walls as I think it goes with everything.

What do you like most about the room now?

VW: The feeling of space. Also it's so relaxing lying in the bath with the radio on, and I can use my church chair beside it to balance a book and a glass of wine.

Sourcebook

  • Bath, bath taps and sink, ebay.co.uk
  • Shower, drench.co.uk
  • Shower screen, bathroommountain.co.uk
  • WC, heatandplumb.com
  • Drawers, Facebook Marketplace
  • Wall and floor tiles, mandarinstone.com
  • Mirror, grahamandgreen.co.uk
  • Wall lights, pooky.com.
  • Light switch, dowsingandreynolds.com
  • Walls in Setting Plaster matt emulsion, farrow-ball.com.
  • Basket with plant, homesense.com.

What it cost

  • Bath £50
  • Bath taps £50
  • Basin £120
  • Basin taps £110
  • Shower £100
  • Shower screen £159
  • WC £200
  • Drawers £50
  • Tiles £550
  • Mirror £179
  • Lights & switch £200
  • Paint £105
  • Total £1,823

Follow House Beautiful on TikTok and Instagram.

item.title: 15 small bathroom ideas to maximise your space
item.description:
Expert tips and stylish ideas to help you make the most of a small bathroom.

If you're on the hunt for smart small bathroom ideas to make the most of a compact space, the chances are you're not alone.

According to Richard Ticehurst, brand expert at Crosswater Bathrooms: 'The average bathroom is just 2.3m x 2.7m in size, so many homeowners are looking for creative ways to maximise space and create the illusion of a bigger room.'

The good news is there are a whole host of clever tricks and design choices you can use to enhance this sometimes tricky space and make your small bathroom look – and feel – like a beautiful retreat. Whether you're looking for budget small bathroom ideas to maximise your space or want to create a spa-like luxury bathroom, we've picked the brains of some of the UK's top bathroom design experts and gathered our favourite small bathroom ideas for inspiration.

How to make a small bathroom look bigger

Bathroom expert Richard recommends looking for space-saving bathroom cabinets and fittings when renovating a small bathroom: 'Wall-hung basins, vanity units and toilets work well as they free up additional floor space, giving the illusion of a bigger room.

'Another quick way of creating the illusion of a bigger bathroom is to invest in bathroom mirrors,' he adds. 'Natural light creates the illusion of greater size and space, so the more of it you have, the better.'

Small bathroom storage is your friend, as clutter instantly makes a space feel more cramped. Look for vertical storage solutions, like shelving, where floor space is tight, and make the most of your shower or bath with nook storage, caddies and shower-hung shelving where possible.

Barrie Cutchie, design director at BC Designs, also has the following advice to make a small bathroom look bigger: 'When space is tight, the key is to distract the eye. This can be done by choosing a statement piece, such as a bath, in a colour other than white, as colour draws the eye in and helps to create a striking focal point.'

What is the best flooring for a small bathroom?

Nothing is off limits when it comes to flooring options for a small bathroom. As it's a smaller surface area to cover, consider splashing out on a high quality stone or tile that will elevate the space. Even bold colours or patterned tiles can work when paired with plainer walls.

Large format tiles are a particularly clever choice for small bathroom flooring, as the lack of grout lines means there are fewer visual breaks which gives the illusion of a bigger space.

15 small bathroom ideas

Discover our top pick of small bathroom ideas, encompassing everything from smart storage and clever design solutions to bold colours and pretty patterns.
item.author: Cara Laskaris
item.category: Decorate,Home,Home Improvement,App: Bathroom Renovations,App: Bathroom Trends,Interior Design,Bathroom
item.source: 15 small bathroom ideas to maximise your space

media:content.media:title: 15 smart small bathroom ideas
media:content.media:description: Expert tips and stylish ideas to help you make the most of a small bathroom.

item.title: The bathroom renovation trends defining 2023, according to Houzz
item.author: Holly Ransome
item.category: Decorate,Home,Home Improvement,App: Bathroom Renovations,App: Bathroom Trends,Interior Design,Bathroom,Interior design, garden and lifestyle trends
item.source: The bathroom renovation trends defining 2023, according to Houzz

media:content.media:title: Bathroom trends defining 2023, according to Houzz
media:content.media:description: From energy efficient but luxurious bathrooms, to shower upgrades and plant-inspired havens, here are the biggest bathroom trends in 2023.
media:content.media:credit: Chris Snook / Amy Stoddart Studio Ltd

item.content:encoded:
Home renovation and design platform Houzz has just released its 2023 bathroom trends report, putting the spotlight on how we're designing and styling the most private room in the house.

The report gathers findings from more than 400 homeowners who are in the midst of, are planning, or recently completed a bathroom project. From energy efficient but luxurious bathrooms, to shower upgrades and plant-inspired havens, bathroom renovations that balance aesthetic desires with functional necessities remain key this year. Read on to find out more...

Spacious showers

A whopping 68 per cent of us have increased the size of our showers (32 per cent have at least doubled them in size). Out of the one in five who removed bathtubs, 82 per cent did so to gain a roomier shower, and while preference for a daily shower over a bath is not a big surprise, it's exciting to see that we want to elevate our daily shower ritual.

Waterfall for the win

While we're on the topic, another trend is the move towards waterfall showers – 78 per cent of us treated ourselves to one. We are choosing to invest in our self-care, hence the notion of the sanctuary-inspired spathroom. The cost of a new showerhead is a small price to pay for the daily therapeutic benefit of water pummelling on your shoulders. Add a few drops of essential oil or hang some dried eucalyptus for the full spa experience.

Bathtime for two

However, that's not to say that baths are a thing of the past. Plenty of us still love our daily soak – in fact, one in three have opted for a stylish freestanding tub and a significant 43 per cent have upgraded to a bath big enough to fit two people. The probable reason? Wanting more room for a fully immersive soak or to make space for a loved one.

Technology is our friend

Consistently the results show us that in the bathroom we're making the most of technological advances. We want our appliances to function with ease. We're upgrading to digital shower control features and nearly one in three of us bought a new toilet with high-tech functionality and automatic features.

Houseplants are a must

This one is not particularly surprising because we've become a country of obsessive houseplant owners in the last decade. For most of us, houseplants are now key to our bathroom styling. We love them for their mood-boosting properties and air-purifying benefits, not forgetting that they look great too. Choose carefully though, the steamy environment of bathrooms won't suit every plant.

We're wary of colour

While generally we seem to be embracing more colour in our homes, in the bathroom we're still playing it safe. White continues to be the top choice, followed by grey and then beige. It seems we want these spaces to remain neutral, calm and quiet. It's not surprising really for the rooms in which we unwind at the end of the day.

Modern and minimalist

Almost 70 per cent are choosing to design bathrooms in a contemporary or modern style, with less than one in 10 decorating traditionally. What's more, we want our bathrooms to look uncluttered and function with ease. A rise in features like low-curb showers, wall-mounted toilets and basins, soft-close drawers and doors, and inbuilt organisers are signs that we want our bathrooms to be well organised, super streamlined and function smoothly. It's the Marie Kondo era in full swing.

The environment comes first

There is evidence we are making decisions with the environment in mind. Opting for energy efficient systems like radiant heating, choosing showers over baths, and prioritising efficiency in our appliances, are all indicators that we're putting sustainability at the centre.

Follow House Beautiful on TikTok and Instagram.
